benchmark_config.jira_title: Implement/Test API: GET /1.0/kb/accounts/{accountId} - Retrieve an account by id

covered: Valid Request: Comprehensive positive scenarios (TC01, TC02, TC03, TC06, TC27–TC33, TC30) validate successful retrieval with default and many query-parameter combinations.

Query Parameters: Extensive coverage of accountWithBalance, accountWithBalanceAndCBA and audit parameter permutations including valid, missing, empty, conflicting and unsupported values (TC02–TC06, TC23–TC25, TC28–TC29, TC31–TC33).
Path Parameter Validation & Errors: Malformed UUID (TC09) and well-formed-but-missing UUID (TC08, TC07) validate 400 and 404 behaviors as required by the story.
Authorization (Authentication) Checks: Missing and invalid token scenarios are covered (TC10, TC11) to ensure authentication failures return 401.

Error & Resilience Handling: System unavailable (TC12 -> 503), timeout/long-running (TC16), transient network retry (TC26), and degraded dependent-service behavior / partial content (TC20) are included.
Security: Injection and XSS attempt handling (TC13, TC14) ensure invalid inputs are rejected and no sensitive data leaked.
Edge cases, scalability & robustness: Extra parameters ignored (TC15), large payload handling (TC17), concurrency (TC18), backward compatibility and regression tests (TC19, TC22) are present.
Default behaviour and response composition: Tests assert omission of balance/CBA by default and audit default NONE behavior (TC01, TC24, TC30).
gaps: Caching Behavior: No tests assert response caching headers (ETag, Cache-Control) or conditional GET handling (If-None-Match / 304 Not Modified).
Rate Limiting / Throttling: No tests to provoke or validate 429 responses, Retry-After behavior, or server throttling under sustained request bursts.

Schema & Response Header Validation: The suite does not explicitly validate the Account JSON schema (field types, required/optional fields) or assert response headers such as Content-Type: application/json.
Authorization (Authorization vs Authentication): Role/permission-based access control (403 Forbidden) or scope-limited token scenarios are not covered—only authentication failures (401) are tested.

Pagination for embedded collections: If the Account response includes large embedded lists (transactions, invoices), pagination and paging parameters are not tested (TC17 touches large payloads but does not verify paging behavior).

Additional server error scenarios: Deterministic tests for other 5xx responses (500, 502, 504) and for rate-limit-induced errors (429) are missing or only partially addressed (TC16 mentions possible 504 but not explicit tests).
Parameter variants & content negotiation: Variants for boolean representations (1/0/yes/no/True), case-sensitivity for audit values, and Accept header / 406 behavior are not tested.
recommendations: Add caching/conditional GET tests: assert ETag and Cache-Control on 200 responses and validate If-None-Match / If-Modified-Since returning 304 when appropriate.
Add rate-limiting and throttling tests: generate high request rates to verify 429 responses, Retry-After headers, and client backoff behavior.

Introduce JSON schema validation: for each successful response assert the Account object matches the canonical JSON schema (types, required fields, nested objects) and add explicit Content-Type header assertions.
Expand authorization tests to include authorization (403) scenarios: test tokens lacking required scopes/roles and verify RBAC/ACL behavior.
If account payloads include nested lists, add pagination tests for those collections (limit/offset or cursor-based paging), and test behavior with very large collections.
Add deterministic server-error tests: simulate/force 500/502/504 and assert the expected status codes and safe error payloads (no sensitive data leakage).
Add parameter-format and content-negotiation tests: boolean parameter variants (1/0/yes/no/True), audit value case variants, and requests with non-JSON Accept headers (expect 406 or proper handling).
Add negative and observability checks: ensure error responses do not leak internal details and that relevant headers (Request-Id, Retry-After) are present for tracing and client behavior.
